ED9C26A43D6A4CF1AC788031E2C5A16B.description:
Students participate productively in discussions, plan agendas with clear goals and deadlines, set
time limits for speakers, take notes, and vote on key issues.

A4D637DCF3DF41B8B0B4CEEB21A50646.description:
Students work productively with other teams. Students will continue to apply earlier
standards with greater complexity.

DEB99854548341788689CB1C000380A3.description:
Students advocate a position using anecdotes, analogies, and/or illustrations, and use eye contact,
speaking rate, volume, enunciation, a variety of natural gestures, and conventions of
language to communicate ideas

C8E6E0EE8A0F4F8FAE5A57F7885B6B86.description:
Students speak clearly and to the point, using the conventions of language. Students
will continue to apply earlier standards with greater complexity.

226EF0EC6DBC40E792AA0C027BB7B2E7.description:
Students draw conclusions about the speaker’s message by considering verbal communication (e.
g., word choice, tone) and nonverbal cues (e.g., posture, gestures, facial expressions).

726C1CD3EDD343D68D3B2BDD1193BADB.description:
Students follow and give complex oral instructions to perform specific tasks, answer questions, or
solve problems.

175A0EB2DEC64B0A97140D32129D8858.description:
Students listen to and interpret a speaker’s purpose by explaining the content, evaluating the
delivery of the presentation, and asking questions or making comments about the
evidence that supports a speaker’s claims.

5857124701784ADEA6D686F03296BA20.description:
Students use comprehension skills to listen attentively to others in formal and
informal settings. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater
complexity.

0477A7C34D774D7C9E1A6CCC808861AC.description:
Students spell correctly, using using various resources to determine and check correct
spellings.

4331CBCC9FCA4D60BB16811022437327.description: semicolons, colons, hyphens, parentheses, brackets. and ellipses.

13C3793BEBBB400D9E76030204BF99B8.description:
commas after introductory structures and dependent adverbial clauses, and correct
punctuation of complex sentences.

0183AD0A17BE4859AD1796E6AB75E2DC.description:
Students write legibly and use appropriate capitalization and punctuation conventions
in their compositions. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater
complexity.

38782E112BF441DCBBF2FDF50DDD8FB4.description: Students recognize & avoid fused sentences, comma splices, and fragment errors.

DBFBDFFD981E4C47966DAC1891270E2E.description:
Students use a variety of complete sentences (e.g., simple, compound, complex) that include
properly placed modifiers, correctly identified antecedents, parallel structures, and
consistent tenses,

EB024151A9BE432A9218BA2F80DBCDA5.description: Students write complex sentences and differentiate between main versus subordinate clauses.

C9D5950548CA419D807E69B044FE8D7B.description: adverbial and adjectival phrases and clauses.

657D8E1D39BE4F0EB8EA96408069D06E.description: cases of personal pronouns and correct usage of relative pronouns,

F56D480EE03044ECA10E482CFB157D4F.description: verbs (perfect and progressive tenses) and participles,

7E74D74BFDB749FFA701B77064BC83B4.description:
Students use and understand the function of the eight parts of speech in the context of reading,
writing, and speaking:

02B067DF1BF34CC8A4D9E829C55B12CF.description:
Students understand the function of and use the conventions of academic language
when speaking and writing. Students will continue to apply earlier standards with
greater complexity.

512F47DA214A4793AF2C3152297ED40D.description:
Presentation follows accepted formats for integrating quotations and citations into the written text to
maintain the flow of ideas.

483EDBC526854E75899D2338BC78083B.description: Presentation demonstrates the findings in a meaningful format.

69124C5F850940CFBAEE6A85A0A84230.description: Presentation draws conclusions and summarizes or paraphrases the findings in a systematic way.

F69C512E381B4C2AB3D750280E2595F8.description: Presentation marshals evidence to explain the topic and give relevant reasons for conclusion.

A626FABFDCC5498788702B76A69586B4.description:
Students organize and present their ideas and information according to the purpose of
research and their audience. Students are expected to synthesize the research into a
written or an oral presentation that:

BC3543F8F04D476B8D9E8940D1229F0E.description:
Students utilize elements that demonstrate the reliability and validity of the sources used (e.g.,
publication, date, coverage, language, point of view) and explain why one source is more
useful and relevant than another

6A2A6FB3B0584DAC906083595A94FC2E.description:
Students can narrow or broaden the major research questions, if necessary, based on further research
and investigation.

A386DB703E2C4A27A2721EB207BA853F.description: Students clarify research questions and evaluate and synthesize collected information.

1BE57F4F14424C759831E4514816BD57.description:
Students differentiate between paraphrasing and plagiarism and identify the importance of citing
valid and reliable sources.

5EBFE7DE5A844D128DBB9C4EBEE15DF2.description:
Students record bibliographic information (e.g., author, title, page number) for all notes and
sources according to standard format;

BA40BB8B4E2B4CF9930D4BED06F1B948.description:
Students categorize information thematically in order to see the larger constructs inherent in
information.

70E0CC02A9384FC2A5F89F8D40C0454C.description:
Students follow the research plan to collect data from a range of relevant print and electronic
sources.

EE631E5D76FF4DD6ABA85D63E6C27F34.description:
Students determine, locate, and explore the full range of relevant sources addressing a
research question and systematically record the information they gather.

6C0F6B6C0395499BA2E2CE7E2E1DF041.description:
Students apply steps for obtaining and evaluating information from a wide variety of sources and
create a written plan after preliminary research in reference works and additional text
searches.

EA8DE432D51542B0A42C1437CE250CE8.description:
Students brainstorm, consult with others, decide upon a topic, and formulate a major research
topic.

C70E022FAEDC4E7F9D934FCA573C3DC4.description: Students ask open-ended research questions and develop a plan for answering them.

A874A0BDDEDD45899F53C6D1ACE30307.description:
Persuasive text includes evidence that is logically organized to support the author’s viewpoint and that
differentiates between fact and opinion.

D992D4B0BE714C30904C85EDE6C47AA2.description:
Persuasive text considers and responds to the views of others and anticipates and answers readers
concerns and counter argument.

4C0FAD993BFC4CB0A7A69C7B3C4DD547.description: Persuasive text establishes a clear thesis or position.

09E4CE145DDE4C62B677E9EF1CE78363.description:
Students write persuasive texts to influence the attitudes or actions of a specific
audience on specific issues.

ACE74DFBE03749208BD4F0644E85887E.description:
Students produce a multimedia presentation involving text and graphic using available
technology.

14E824851ADA4861A25B677739775A2A.description:
Students can write responses to literary or expository texts that demonstrate the writing skills for
multi-paragraph essays and provide sustained evidence from the text using quotations
when appropriate.

7C9077F766EA4D6D802237624088DE3F.description:
Students can write a letter that reflects an opinion, registers a complaint, or requests information in a
business or friendly context.

DDE293C0FDBE44ABBB585BC7EA184E8A.description: Multi-paragraph essay accurately synthesizes ideas from several sources

D9F26A6D7AFE42F7973B86CE6E8086EE.description:
Multi-paragraph essay uses a variety of sentence structures, rhetorical devices, and transitions to link
paragraph

A60F465CF73E414094837C669DBB2E73.description:
Multi-paragraph essay is logically organized with appropriate facts and details and includes no extraneous
information or inconsistencies;

4CD5E59692BD45129EA529B0F98A8400.description: Multi-paragraph essay contains a clearly stated purpose and controlling idea;

2148E3DD459442688953356159462FFD.description: Multi-paragraph essay presents effective introductions and concluding paragraphs;

A09D6C2B39FA441A838B2EA5C3B049AC.description: Students write a multi-paragraph essay to convey information about a topic that:

EA913B86C7EA486EBF5E8571E9737AAD.description:
Students write expository and procedural or work-related texts to communicate ideas
and information to specific audiences for specific purposes.

1C507709E2AB43109E643F05D561A80A.description:
Students write a personal narrative that has a clearly defined focus and communicates the
importance of or reasons for actions and/or consequence

DD0FA889FE0E434896432CCF940A208C.description: Students write about their own experiences

6CD1B40E9BD949EDB4ADA47563E0FC7E.description: The imaginative story uses a range of literary strategies and devices to enhance style and tone.

764947E046FD4350ACB34F31D63D8D9A.description: The imaginative story develops interesting characters;

152D875009C84D13A4EE1073096582DA.description: The imaginative story creates a specific, believable setting through the use of sensory details;

4ABF962F2F7641A398C5B0344E796944.description: The imaginative story includes well-paced action and an engaging story line;

B9E235D52A9F4DD7BFD836E35BF9C7E8.description: The imaginative story sustains reader interest;

EEF1C1010FFC418C87F0DA125D9C3496.description: Students write an imaginative story that includes typical elements at grade-level proficiency.

F9E3D0DAADD94C44B69ECC39BFB49F84.description:
Students write literary texts to express their ideas and feelings about real or imagined
people, events, and ideas.

A78EC7B109A14421AC4BABBDA27DF922.description:
Students revise final draft in response to feedback from peers and teacher and publish written
work for appropriate audiences.

6CC1717B177D4CB2929728E5897FCFE5.description: Students edit drafts for grammar, mechanics, and spelling.

139606FF52124138B74C25428C0760C4.description:
Students revise drafts to ensure precise word choice and vivid images; consistent point of view;
use of simple, compound, and complex sentences; internal and external coherence; and
the use of effective transitions after rethinking how well questions of purpose, audience,
and genre have been addressed.

E47EA97D80894E6AA3EB896EFD3109E4.description:
Students develop drafts by choosing an appropriate organizational strategy (e.g., sequence of
events, cause-effect, compare-contrast) and building on ideas to create a focused,
organize, and coherent piece of writing.

69FD23F81ED2411B8D5FB1FA154B0522.description:
Students plan a first draft appropriate for conveying the intended meaning to an audience,
determining appropriate topics through a range of strategies and developing a thesis or
controlling idea.

AFCC4D00ECF84943990F66545E43EAB9.description:
Students use the elements of the writing process (planning, drafting, revising, editing,
and publishing) to compose text.

D177C4992DA3425B878F65F2F7BE30B3.description:
Students assess the correct level of formality and tone for successful participation in various
digital media.

7FA53FE43CAF49AC81CE73467FEF2F2F.description:
Students evaluate various techniques used to create a point of view in media and the impact on
audience.

4468923668584266801C0D4DA8002D27.description:
Students interpret how visual and sound techniques (e.g., special effects, camera angles, lighting,
music) influence the message.

871E14A1E54349A7A373A824C6263B36.description:
Students evaluate the role of media in focusing attention on events and informing opinion on
issues.

E0B805449D1E4E029BF50E037794AE25.description:
Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and
sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning. Students will continue to
apply earlier standards with greater depth in increasingly complex texts.

38015C9E340546E28728697B834610A2.description: Students evaluate graphics for their clarity in communicating meaning or achieving a specific purpose.

F7A18065CFE74E28BE068A70B6E75346.description:
Students analyze text for missing or extraneous information in multi-step directions or legends for
diagrams.

CEC2994F12334AC8A0A4D548A1064663.description:
Students understand how to glean and use information in procedural texts and
documents.

1B3DC395DF7F4E98BF0EED374D7AC6C9.description:
Students analyze the use of such rhetorical and logical fallacies as loaded terms, caricatures,
leading questions, false assumptions, and incorrect premises in persuasive texts.

45747B21D61949C7B30D4644C744EECA.description:
Students compare and contrast persuasive texts that reached different conclusions about the
same issue and explain how authors reached their conclusions through analyzing the
evidence each presents.

A6BA3B9FF8F94A0E99BE067F22196B99.description:
Students analyze, make inferences, and draw conclusions about persuasive text and
provide evidence of their reading.

F6963B1ED42A4D9692DA0C60CF6A5DB3.description:
Students synthesize and make logical connections between ideas within a text and across two or
three texts representing similar or different genres, and support those findings with
textual evidence.

4E84CFB746B34E9186A4F3C8AF064BA1.description:
Students make subtle inferences and draw complex conclusions about the ideas in text and their
organizational patterns.

1263C808C1624E01B4D119E7DC13A6EC.description:
Students distinguish factual claims from commonplace assertions and opinions and evaluate
inferences from their logic in text.

0BAE7DFFE1CE4BB486B4A0A677CC57DF.description:
Students summarize the main ideas, supporting details, and relationships among ideas in text
succinctly in ways that maintain meaning and logical order.

6A74B5A5D1624E83BCA28AD3EE969A2C.description:
Students analyze, make inferences, and draw conclusions about expository text and
provide evidence of their reading.

A981EB07F2414BCD8772470D57147A21.description:
Students analyze works written on the same topic and compare how the authors achieved similar
or different purposes.

5159C92EA87547B99DA3B44DDDEC3B96.description:
Students analyze, make inferences, and draw conclusions about the author’s purpose
in cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text
to support their understanding.

972EEE4D0A71443BB61D33A7AE29EA48.description:
Students read independently for a sustained period of time and summarize or paraphrase what
the reading was about, maintaining meaning and logical order (e.g., generate a reading
log or journal; participate in book talks).

4F88B0D7C5D74531A26AF623864EC8C4.description:
Students read independently for sustained periods of time and provide evidence of
their reading.

1D2323BE8D3A4B3D82A0D56488F2BBD6.description: Students explain the effect of similes and extended metaphors in literary text.

D445BF3E14ED4B75B2D4888BA1CA125F.description:
Students understand, make inferences, and draw conclusions about how an author’s
sensory language creates imagery in literary text and provide evidence from text to
support their understanding.

7B23307DC23E4F549421AE0DB2CC811C.description:
Students analyze passages in well-known speeches for the author’s use of literary device and
word and phrase choice (e.g. aphorisms, epigraphs) to appeal to the audience.

A09ACE4B6FC84B9AA1648FF40BAAA5D6.description:
Students understand, make inferences, and draw conclusions about the varied
structural patterns and features of literary nonfiction and provide evidence from text
to support their understanding.

61A4B6CD1D5C442D9F6F084AC0F65786.description:
Students analyze different forms of point of view, including limited versus omniscient, subjective
versus objective.

C7CE4C05343D4355A43F7A5235F24F59.description:
Students analyze how the central characters’ qualities influence the theme of a fictional work and
resolution of the central conflict.

6A6096710A11400DAE611C47C6074847.description:
Students analyze linear plot developments (e.g., conflict, rising action, falling action, resolution,
subplots) to determine whether and how conflicts are resolved.

2BA372C5131D4D358CA147E6A1E92764.description:
Students understand, make inferences, and draw conclusions about the structure and
elements of fiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding.

09807499EE624CACA5E5BB4576CF6F20.description:
Students analyze how different playwrights characterize their protagonists and antagonists
through dialogue and staging of their plays.

605142859FA64897A6204103B0D99450.description:
Students understand, make inferences, and draw conclusions about the structure and
elements of drama and provide evidence from text to support their understanding.

526A5738014B4A388B136CF9C93B2E72.description:
Students compare and contrast the relationship between the purpose and characteristics of
different poetic forms (e.g., epic poetry, lyric poetry).

AC75A83E2C6B448B9D9B4D825AC226D6.description:
Students understand, make inferences, and draw conclusions about the structure and
elements of poetry and provide evidence from text to support their understanding.

7238FC400E3F428C8740DFE6D77C7F4B.description: Students explain how the values and beliefs of particular characters are affected by the historical and cultural setting of a literary work.

C89FFADF3BE74E3EB977587C9D590E41.description: Students compare and contrast the similarities and differences in mythologies from various cultures (e.g., ideas of afterlife, roles and characteristics of deities, purposes of myth).

5EC7FA10D8054C51B6C12551C6C3BB65.description: Students andalyze literary works that share similar themes across cultures.

0B72E3914E13473BAE38C4310E1FBF35.description: Students understand, make inferences, and draw conclusions about theme and genre in different cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and provide evidence from the text to support their understanding.

60819C59CE534F6E8DDCA5F7B750B674.description: Students use a dictionary, a glossary, or thesaurus (printed or electronic) to determine the meanings, syllabication, pronunciation, alternate word choices, and parts of speech of words.

7B7CF9FE800D4D7088C096FFCCD17CD7.description: Students identify common words or word parts from other languages that are used in written English (e.g., phenomenon, charisma, chorus, passe', flora, fauna).

8055D53A67234452B0C0425A26A26D10.description: Students complete analogies that describe a function or its description (e.g., pen:paper::chalk:____ or soft:kitten::hard:____).

F6C1607940164B0DA20C429B17CB9BDA.description: Students use context (within a sentence and in larger sections of text) to determine or clarify the meaning of unfamiliar or ambiguous words or words with novel meaning.

6DC4FF6165DF4501A72F94FA0C571B09.description: Students explain the meaning of foreign words and phrases commonly used in written English (e.g., RSVP, que sera sera).

F45FD72582C34123A5C76D9053DF6D6C.description: Students determine the meaning of grade-level academic English words derived from Latin, Greek, or other linguistic roots and affixes.

26ADD3ED502E455C8592685D8290E416.description: Students understand new vocabulary and use it when reading and writing.

F720F515E3134A25A1CC5D0CE3CE9356.description: Students are expected to adjust fluency when reading aloud grade-level text based on the reading purpose and the nature of the text.

8AF53116EBFD4BB68C6CD58083502EF2.description: Students read grade-level text with fluency and comprehension.
